input_prompt:
Extract all factual claims from this YouTube transcript:

“Give me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses yearning to breathe free…” These poetic lines, engraved on a bronze plaque beneath the Statue of Liberty, speak to who we are: a nation of immigrants. Until now . . . As Senate Democrat Chuck Schumer lamented, “Tears are running down the cheeks of the Statue of Liberty.” We’ve turned our backs on those huddled masses. Closed our borders. Separated families. Hardened our hearts. Or so you would think if you only read the headlines or watch TV news. Just one problem: It’s not true. The United States still maintains the most generous immigration policies in the world. Generous to a fault...because the overwhelming numbers have stymied our ability to assimilate the huddled masses. 50 million residents of America are foreign-born. In fact, today the United States has more immigrants as a percentage of its total population than at any time since 1890. That’s why, to give one illustration, 176 different languages are spoken among students in the New York City school system. How did we get here? For starters, America grants permanent residence to a million people every single year. And that’s just the tip of the iceberg because of something you’ve probably heard referred to as “chain migration.” Chain migration allows immigrants to sponsor not only their immediate family—parents, spouses and children under age 21, but much of their extended family once they gain citizenship: unmarried adult children and any children they might have, married adult children and their children, and brothers and sisters and their children. Princeton University researchers, using the most recently available data, found that immigrants sponsored an average of 3.45 additional relatives each. So, the one million immigrants granted permanent residence each year potentially adds, over time, another three and a half million. In addition, an estimated 100,000 refugees and asylum-seekers—people who claim to be fleeing political or personal strife abroad—enter the country annually. From 2008 to 2017, the U.S. gave green cards to well over a million people for humanitarian reasons, allowing them to live and work here permanently. After five years, they can apply for full citizenship. We’re not done yet. In that same time frame, nearly half a million more people came to America through the diversity visa lottery—a program designed to admit more people from “underrepresented” countries into the U.S. Diversity visa applicants don't need a high school education, job skills —or pretty much anything. And, thanks again to chain migration, spouses and unmarried children under 21 of visa lottery winners also get to come to America. This non-stop flow of new legal immigrants—based on family ties instead of skills, abilities, and allegiance to American values—has, of course, been supplemented by millions who enter the country illegally and stay illegally. Dominant media outlets use the euphemism “undocumented,” but the official U.S. government term used in federal statutes is “illegal alien”: an unlawful entrant who came without permission and stays in open defiance of our laws. The number of illegal aliens in the country is usually given as 11 million, but have you noticed that number never seems to change? Common sense suggests it’s higher—much higher. And though illegal aliens themselves don’t qualify for welfare, they receive free health care in our clinics and hospitals, and through their American-born children they can expect to receive all manner of benefits—cash aid, food stamps, and housing vouchers. Their children are entitled to a free education in public schools. Building a high-tech border barrier would certainly help stem this flow. Ending chain migration is another obvious remedy. E-Verify, the national database that allows employers to check workers’ immigration status, is also essential. So is a fully-functioning entry-exit system to track visa overstayers. But all solutions will ultimately fail unless we get control of the numbers and enforce our laws consistently. It’s Sovereignty 101: This is our home and we have not only the right, but the responsibility, to determine who comes in, how many come in, and what qualities and qualifications they bring. The truth is, we let in millions. And, of course, millions more want to come. Who can blame them? But it’s simply not possible or desirable to let in everyone. And it’s not hateful to say so. It’s not hateful to protect our borders. It’s not hateful to protect our citizens. It’s not hateful to protect our values. Lady Liberty may be shedding tears—not because we’ve stopped welcoming immigrants, but because our ill-conceived immigration policies are threatening the American Dream. I’m Michelle Malkin, CRTV host and author of Invasion and Sold Out, for Prager University.

The United States maintains the most generous immigration policies in the world.

claims.text: 50 million residents of America are foreign-born.

176 different languages are spoken among students in the New York City school system.

Immigrants sponsored an average of 3.45 additional relatives each.
An estimated 100,000 refugees and asylum-seekers enter the country annually.
From 2008 to 2017, the U.S. gave green cards to well over a million people for humanitarian reasons.
Nearly half a million more people came to America through the diversity visa lottery from 2008 to 2017.
The number of illegal aliens in the country is usually given as 11 million.

claims.text: Illegal aliens receive free health care in clinics and hospitals.

claims.text: Their children are entitled to a free education in public schools.

A fully-functioning entry-exit system is essential to track visa overstayers.

input_prompt:
Claim: 176 different languages are spoken among students in the New York City school system.
Category: statistical
Extraction confidence: 0.90

Evidence:
UNCLEAR (5 sources):
  1. 2023 | NYC PUBLIC SCHOOLS - English Language Learners Data | reliability=high (1.00)
     URL: https://data.nysed.gov/ell.php?year=2023&instid=7889678368
     Summary: NYC PUBLIC SCHOOLS ENGLISH LANGUAGE LEARNERS ENROLLMENT (2022 - 23). K-12 ELL Enrollment: 143,080. K-12 Former ELL Enrollment: 54,131 ...
  2. NYCPS Data at a Glance | reliability=high (1.00)
     URL: https://www.schools.nyc.gov/about-us/reports/nycps-data-at-a-glance
     Summary: School Environment; NYC Public Schools Speak Your Language; Understanding Respect for All: NYCPS's Commitment to Safe and Supportive Learning Environment ...
  3. [PDF] The New York State Seal of Biliteracy Annual Report (2023-24) - ERIC | reliability=high (0.90)
     URL: https://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/ED673399.pdf
     Summary: The NYSSB is an award that formally recognizes students who have attained a high level of proficiency in two or more world languages (one of which must be ...
  4. Language Access Policy - NYC Public Schools | reliability=high (0.90)
     URL: https://www.schools.nyc.gov/about-us/policies/language-access-policy
     Summary: These languages are Albanian, Arabic, Bangla, Chinese, French, Haitian Creole, Korean, Russian, Spanish, Ukrainian, Urdu and Uzbek. These languages, including ...
  5. [PDF] Our Schools Speak Your Language | reliability=medium (0.60)
     URL: https://pwsblobprd.schools.nyc/prd-pws/docs/default-source/default-document-library/enrollment/36504-ps-you-issue-44---language-diversity-english.pdf?sfvrsn=838525d4_2
     Summary: Dear New Yorkers,. Our students and families speak over 180 languages. 180 ... of 12 languages, ranging from Bengali to Haitian Creole, Japanese to Polish.

Provide the structured verdict.

output.summary: The evidence presents conflicting information regarding the number of languages spoken among students in NYC schools. While one source indicates that students and families speak over 180 languages, another source does not confirm the specific number of 176 languages, leading to uncertainty.

input_prompt:
Claim: The number of illegal aliens in the country is usually given as 11 million.
Category: statistical
Extraction confidence: 0.90

Evidence:
UNCLEAR (5 sources):
  1. Estimates of the Illegal Alien Population Residing in the United States | reliability=high (0.90)
     URL: https://ohss.dhs.gov/topics/immigration/illegal/population-estimates
     Summary: Office of Homeland Security Statistics report on illegal (or unauthorized) aliens (or immigrants) for FY 1990-2022 by period of entry, ...
  2. A Turning Point for the Unauthorized Immigrant Pop.. | reliability=high (0.85)
     URL: https://www.migrationpolicy.org/news/turning-point-us-unauthorized-immigrant-population
     Summary: Approximately 11.2 million unauthorized immigrants lived in the United States in 2021, up from 11.0 million in 2019, according to new Migration Policy ...
  3. Record 14 Million Unauthorized Immigrants Lived in the US in 2023 | reliability=high (0.85)
     URL: https://www.pewresearch.org/race-and-ethnicity/2025/08/21/u-s-unauthorized-immigrant-population-reached-a-record-14-million-in-2023/
     Summary: In the years after the COVID-19 pandemic, U.S. immigration policy changes fueled a sharp rise in both legal and illegal immigration.
  4. Unauthorized immigrants and the economy - Economic Policy Institute | reliability=high (0.85)
     URL: https://www.epi.org/publication/unauthorized-immigrants/
     Summary: Robert Warren, US Undocumented Population Increased to 11.7 Million in July 2023: Provisional CMS Estimates Derived from CPS Data, Center for ...
  5. What we know about unauthorized immigrants living in the U.S. | reliability=high (0.85)
     URL: https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2024/07/22/what-we-know-about-unauthorized-immigrants-living-in-the-us/
     Summary: The unauthorized immigrant population in the U.S. grew to 11 million in 2022, but remained below the peak of 12.2 million in 2007.

Provide the structured verdict.

output.summary: Estimates of the illegal alien population in the U.S. vary, with some sources reporting around 11 million (e.g., Migration Policy report) while others indicate higher figures, such as 14 million (Pew Research). This discrepancy suggests that the commonly cited figure of 11 million may not reflect the current reality.

input_prompt:
Claim: Nearly half a million more people came to America through the diversity visa lottery from 2008 to 2017.
Category: statistical
Extraction confidence: 0.80

Evidence:
UNCLEAR (4 sources):
  1. [PDF] Immigrant Number Use for Visa Issuances and Adjustments of ... | reliability=high (1.00)
     URL: https://travel.state.gov/content/dam/visas/Statistics/AnnualReports/FY2017AnnualReport/FY17AnnualReport-TableVII.pdf
     Summary: 2017. Table VII. Immigrant Number Use for Visa Issuances and Adjustments of Status in the Diversity Immigrant. Category. Fiscal Years 2008-2017. Sierra Leone.
  2. Diversity Visa Program Statistics - Travel.gov | reliability=high (0.90)
     URL: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/us-visas/immigrate/diversity-visa-program-entry/diversity-visa-program-statistics.html
     Summary: Diversity Visa Program Statistics · DV Statistics 2019-2021 · DV Statistics 2016-2018 · DV Statistics 2013-2015 · DV Statistics 2010-2012 · DV Statistics 2007-2009.
  3. Yearbook of Immigration Statistics | OHSS | reliability=high (0.90)
     URL: https://ohss.dhs.gov/topics/immigration/yearbook
     Summary: Summarizes a year in immigration, including counts of immigrants by type, including green card holders, and immigration enforcement, ...
  4. US diversity visa lottery saw near-record number of applicants in 2017 | reliability=high (0.85)
     URL: https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2018/08/23/applications-for-u-s-visa-lottery-more-than-doubled-since-2007/
     Summary: More than 22.4 million people applied in 2017 to a U.S. visa program that provides 50,000 green cards, or lawful permanent residence, each year ...

Provide the structured verdict.

output.summary: The evidence regarding the diversity visa lottery from 2008 to 2017 is unclear. While high-reliability sources provide statistics on visa issuances and adjustments, they do not confirm the specific claim of nearly half a million more people coming through the lottery during that period. The data from the Travel.gov and Pew Research sources indicate significant application numbers but do not directly support the claim about the increase in arrivals.
